title: Why do we need to instruct GitPython to clean up?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issue asks a question rather than reporting a problem

body:
Upfront confession: I still do not believe that wrapt is at fault re the notorious segfault.

Please help me understand why this code is required in `GitRepo.__del__`:

````
        # Make sure to flush pending changes, especially close batch processes
        # (internal `git cat-file --batch` by GitPython)
        if hasattr(self, 'repo') and self.repo is not None \
                and exists(self.path):  # gc might be late, so the (temporary)
                                        # repo doesn't exist on FS anymore

            self.repo.git.clear_cache()
            if exists(opj(self.path, '.git')):  # don't try to write otherwise
                self.repo.index.write()
````

This seem to indicate that without our explicit intervention GitPython would leave a repo in some kind of "broken" state. I somehow find that odd and unlikely.

`git blame` says that some parts of this code where added in https://github.com/datalad/datalad/commit/1aeacf711306743ef493b56928cee5062e6df831 by @bpoldrack as a "proper cleanup". I assume, it is related to our reuse approach for Repo instances, but I cannot quite grasp how exactly.

Interestingly, this also included running `precommit()`, which since then has been identified as a source of evil and was removed.

From the commit message it is unclear to me how important this is. In #1635 we can already see that the conditionals in this code are not sufficient. Please let me know what you think about this. I am inclined to simply remove this code.
